results.title: Bwana Devil 3D glasses
results.brief_description: Cardboard and plastic 3D movie glasses that fold open for wearing. Front centre has red printing ‘POLAROID’. Side arms each have red printing ‘Arch Oboler’s’, ‘ “BWANA DEVIL” in NATURAL VISION’. Left arm also has ‘Not for Sunglare or Night Driving’. Right arm also has ‘3-D Viewer No.718’.

results.title: ‘Aboriginal kitsch’ Jedda plate
results.brief_description: Due to Jedda’s popularity and interest in Aboriginal ‘kitsch’ and culture, Arrernte actress Kunoth-Monks and Jedda became entwined. But she never acted again, instead becoming an advocate for Australia’s First Peoples.
results.description: Memorabilia ceramic plate featuring an illustrated portrait of Rosalie Kunoth-Monks from the film Jedda. Plate is round with illustration printed in centre in shades of browns on a creamy white background. Verso of plate is white with two holes related to hainging of plate.
description_for_label: Memorabilia ceramic plate featuring an illustrated portrait of Rosalie Kunoth-Monks from the film Jedda. Plate is round with illustration printed in centre in shades of browns on a creamy white background. Verso of plate is white with two holes related to hainging of plate.

results.title: Nintendo Entertainment System (NES) Power Glove
results.material_description: Sollid and flexible plastic with cloth/material backing.
results.brief_description:
“I love the Power Glove… it’s so bad.” – The Wizard

In 1989, ‘bad’ was slang for cool and there was nothing cooler than the Power Glove. At least, that’s what a generation who believed its marketing thought. Developed by Mattel as an alternative controller for the Nintendo Entertainment System (NES), the Power Glove promised to bridge the human-machine divide through early VR mechanics. Just slip on the glove to control your favourite NES games. Except it didn’t really work - well, not in the seamless way the Nintendo-produced movie The Wizard (1989) promised. The Power Glove’s prototype, the DataGlove, did work, but to be affordable for consumers it was simplified and ended up just… so bad.
results.description:
“I love the Power Glove… it’s so bad.” – Lucas (Jackey Vinson) in The Wizard.

Just slip on the glove to control your favourite NES games. Except it didn’t really work - well, not in the seamless way the Nintendo-produced movie The Wizard (1989) promised. The Power Glove’s prototype, the DataGlove, did work, but to be affordable for consumers it was simplified and ended up just… so bad.

results.title: Mad Max: Fury Road production still
results.brief_description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Bursting with stunning practical effects, explosive set pieces and iconic costumes, the original Mad Max trilogy (1979–85) cemented its place in pop culture before roaring back to life 30 years later.
